stem: The nurse is reviewing the client's electronic health record. Based on the information provided, for each set of arterial blood gas (ABG) values, determine the acid-base imbalance present.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
10:00 SBAR for Mr. Johnson
Situation: Mr. Johnson, a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, was admitted this morning for increased shortness of breath and cough. He has been increasingly lethargic throughout the day.
Background: Mr. Johnson has a long-standing history of COPD and is typically managed at home with oxygen 2L NC. He reports increased sputum production and difficulty breathing over the past 3 days. He missed his last pulmonary rehabilitation appointment.
Assessment: On admission, his vital signs were within his normal baseline. However, over the past several hours, his respiratory rate has increased, and he appears more confused. Current vital signs are in the vital signs tab. ABG results are also available in the lab results tab.
Recommendation: I recommend we consider repeat ABGs to evaluate his respiratory status and consult respiratory therapy for potential ventilator management. Also, please evaluate his mental status and consider further interventions for his altered mental status. 

10:30 SBAR for Mrs. Davis
Situation: Mrs. Davis, a 52-year-old female, post-operative day 1 following a bowel resection, is experiencing persistent nausea and vomiting.
Background: Mrs. Davis underwent a bowel resection yesterday due to a tumor. She has a history of hypertension, managed with lisinopril. She has been reporting severe nausea and has vomited twice this shift.
Assessment: Mrs. Davis is complaining of dizziness. Her vital signs are in the vital signs tab. ABG results are also available in the lab results tab. She is currently NPO and receiving IV fluids. 
Recommendation: I recommend we evaluate her electrolytes and ABGs to assess for acid-base imbalances related to her vomiting. I also recommend continuing antiemetic medications as prescribed.

11:00 SBAR for Mr. Lee
Situation: Mr. Lee, a 30-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes, presented to the emergency department with altered mental status and rapid breathing.
Background: Mr. Lee has a history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes. He reports missing several insulin doses over the past few days. He has been feeling increasingly ill with nausea and abdominal pain.
Assessment: Mr. Lee is lethargic and has Kussmaul respirations. His vital signs are in the vital signs tab. ABG results are also available in the lab results tab. His blood glucose is elevated.
Recommendation: I recommend aggressive fluid resuscitation and insulin administration to address his diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Monitor his electrolytes and ABGs closely.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
LabPatientResultReference Range
pHMr. Johnson7.307.35-7.45
PaCO2Mr. Johnson60 mmHg35-45 mmHg
HCO3Mr. Johnson26 mEq/L22-26 mEq/L
pHMrs. Davis7.507.35-7.45

HCO3Mrs. Davis32 mEq/L22-26 mEq/L
pHMr. Lee7.257.35-7.45

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
PatientFindings
Mr. JohnsonLethargic, coarse crackles auscultated bilaterally, using accessory muscles to breathe.
Mrs. DavisComplaining of nausea, dry mucous membranes, diminished bowel sounds in all quadrants.
Mr. LeeLethargic, Kussmaul respirations, fruity-scented breath, abdominal pain.

rows.text: Mr. Johnson: pH 7.30, PaCO2 60 mmHg, HCO3 26 mEq/L
Mrs. Davis: pH 7.50, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3 32 mEq/L
Mr. Lee: pH 7.25, PaCO2 28 mmHg, HCO3 15 mEq/L

rationale.correct:
Respiratory Acidosis: Mr. Johnson's ABGs show a low pH (7.30) and a high PaCO2 (60 mmHg) with a normal HCO3 (26 mEq/L), indicating respiratory acidosis. This is consistent with his COPD exacerbation, where impaired gas exchange leads to CO2 retention. 
Metabolic Alkalosis: Mrs. Davis' ABGs show a high pH (7.50) and a high HCO3 (32 mEq/L) with a normal PaCO2 (40 mmHg), indicating metabolic alkalosis. This is likely due to persistent vomiting after her bowel resection, leading to loss of gastric acid.
Metabolic Acidosis: Mr. Lee's ABGs show a low pH (7.25) and a low HCO3 (15 mEq/L) with a low PaCO2 (28 mmHg), indicating metabolic acidosis. This is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), where the body produces excess ketones, leading to acidemia.
rationale.incorrect:
Respiratory Alkalosis: This would present with a high pH and low PaCO2.
Normal ABGs: These would fall within the normal reference ranges for pH, PaCO2, and HCO3.
If CO2 and HCO3 are both elevated or depressed it could be a compensation. Assess pH first.

answerBreakdown.text: Mr. Johnson: pH 7.30, PaCO2 60 mmHg, HCO3 26 mEq/L
answerBreakdown.rationale: The low pH and high PaCO2 indicate respiratory acidosis. This aligns with the nurse's note indicating increased shortness of breath and the patient's COPD history.

answerBreakdown.text: Mrs. Davis: pH 7.50, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3 32 mEq/L
answerBreakdown.rationale: The high pH and high HCO3 indicate metabolic alkalosis. This aligns with the nurse's note indicating persistent nausea and vomiting.

answerBreakdown.text: Mr. Lee: pH 7.25, PaCO2 28 mmHg, HCO3 15 mEq/L
answerBreakdown.rationale: The low pH and low HCO3 indicate metabolic acidosis. This aligns with the nurse's note indicating altered mental status, rapid breathing, and a history of type 1 diabetes, suggesting DKA.

clinicalPearls: Always assess the pH first to determine if the patient is acidotic or alkalotic.
Evaluate the PaCO2 to determine if the respiratory system is the cause of the imbalance.
Assess the HCO3 to determine if the metabolic system is the cause of the imbalance.
Consider the patient's clinical presentation and history to understand the underlying cause of the acid-base imbalance.
If the pH is normal, but the PaCO2 and HCO3 are abnormal, the patient may be compensating for a chronic acid-base imbalance.

questionTrap.trap: Students often get confused when the pH is near normal or when there is compensation occurring. They may misinterpret partially compensated ABGs as normal.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on identifying the primary imbalance first by looking at the pH. Then, determine if the PaCO2 or HCO3 is the primary cause. Look for clinical cues to support your interpretation.

mnemonic.title: ROME
mnemonic.expansion: Respiratory Opposite (pH and PaCO2 move in opposite directions), Metabolic Equal (pH and HCO3 move in the same direction)
